comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The number of balls suggests billiards rather than pool.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of March 14, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A14FA385A12738... provides more detail on some of the names: J Ferdinand Poggenburg Eugene L.Milburn Joseph Mayer (or Meyer?) Dr. W.E.Oppenheimer However, the March 16, 1914 NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E5DB1E39E633A... and a close look at the writing on the negative, suggests that it should be Walter E. Uffenheimer, not Oppenheimer,

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of August 5, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70C16FF3B5816738... includes an E.B. Kurtz among a list of amateur billiards players, as well as Poggenburg and Uffenheimer.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I have started an entry in Wikipedia for Poggenburg: Justus Ferdinand Poggenburg III (January 23, 1895 - December 1966) was an American billiards champion en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justus_Ferdinand_Poggenburg_III

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Assuming this is taken at the March 1914 Class A amateur billiards tournament, there is a detailed description of the individual games in Sporting Life of March 21, 1914: www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/SportingLife/1914/VO...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: swanq: Thanks for finding the full and correct names of these folks.   We'll include this information next time we update.
